slides.title: title
slides.content: Provide company name, your name and title, address, email, and cell number.

slides.title: problem/opportunity
slides.content: Describe the pain that you're alleviating or the pleasure you're providing.

slides.title: value proposition
slides.content: Explain the value of the pain you alleviate or the value of the pleasure you provide.

slides.title: underlying magic
slides.content: Describe the technology, secret sauce, or magic behind your product. The less text and the more diagrams, schematics, and flowcharts the better. If you have a prototype or demo, this is the time to transition to it. As Glen Shires of Google said, 'If a picture is worth 1000 words, a prototype is worth 10,000 slides.'

slides.title: business model
slides.content: Explain who has your money temporarily in his pocket and how you're going to get it into yours.

slides.title: go-to-market plan
slides.content: Explain how you are going to reach your customer without breaking the bank.

slides.title: competitive analysis
slides.content: Provide a complete view of the competitive landscape. Too much is better than too little.

slides.title: management team
slides.content: Describe the key players of your management team, board of directors, and board of advisors, as well as your major investors. It's okay if you have less than a perfect team. If your team was perfect, you wouldn't need to be pitching.

slides.title: financial projections and key metrics
slides.content: Provide a three-year forecast containing not only dollars but also key metrics, such as number of customers and conversion rate. Do a bottom-up forecast, not top down.

slides.title: current status, accomplishments to date, timeline, and use of funds
slides.content: Explain the current status of your product, what the near future looks like, and how you'll use the money you're trying to raise.
